author: Richard Kelly
title: RoadRunners whip Jr. Blues 5-0
text:
RoadRunners whip Jr. Blues 5-0 Topeka peppers standout Springfield goaltender Posted: October 16, 2015 - 10:25pm By Richard Kelly The Capital-Journal 
The Topeka RoadRunners have to feel pretty good about their effort in Friday night’s contest against the Springfield Jr. Blues. 
Propelled by two shorthanded tallies, a power-play goal and a shutout from goaltender Tyler Johnson, Topeka (7-6-0) cruised to a 5-0 victory over the Jr. Blues at Landon Arena. 
Coming into the game with a minute 1.64 goals-against average, Springfield goaltender Tommy Nappier was peppered early and often with shots, giving up four goals on the night. 
“He’s an elite goaltender,” RoadRunners coach Scott Langer said. “For our guys to get traffic and pucks at him and get rewarded is huge.” 
Johnson’s shutout was aided by his team’s defense, as the RoadRunners stood large in front of him all night long blocking shots. 
“My teammates made it so easy on me blocking shots,” Johnson said. “I think a game like this is a confidence booster for all of us.” 
A rolling puck trickled through Nappier’s legs to open the scoring at 7:53 of the first. A pass from forward Matt Jennings was deflected off a Jr. Blues stick, but forward Quinn Preston settled the puck and snapped a shot into the net, giving the Runners an early lead. 
It didn’t take long for Topeka to jump on Nappier in the second period. Just 25 seconds in, forward Cam Strong extended the RoadRunner lead with a power-play goal through a screen to make it 2-0. 
The Jr. Blues luck didn’t get much better in the second half of the period. 
While shorthanded, Topeka found itself on a 2-on-0 breakaway, with Jennings beating Nappier glove side high for a 3-0 Runner lead. 
Topeka’s special teams played a decisive factor in the outcome, with three of the five goals scored while even on the power play or shorthanded. 
“When your special teams are on like that, your team has a chance to win every night,” Langer said. “Both penalty kill and power play have been areas we’ve been working on, because they haven’t been our strength, but tonight they were very good.” 
On another odd-man break, Topeka extended its lead to four midway through the third period. At 6:07, Strong slammed home a good feed from forward Luka Maver. 
Forward Yu Hikosaka sealed it late in the third period. With Springfield on a power play, Jr. Blues coach Tony Zasowski pulled Nappier to make it a 6-on-4 power play. It didn’t take long for Hikosaka to flutter the puck into the empty net, making it 5-0. 
The two teams tangle again at 7:05 p.m. Saturday. The first 250 fans will receive a free coozie.
